VOL. XXV. No. 6
TENTATIVE BASKETBALL
SCHEDULE ARRANGED.
Three Letter Men Back—Many Promising Candidates Available—Dances
Will Be Given After Home
Games at Armory.

The Hopkins Basketball Team
is scheduled to open its 1920-21
season at home with the New
York University Team. During
the year a large number of the
• strongest teams in the East will
be met, thus assuring another
successful basketball season.
Of the five regulars who played
on the Varsity team last year,
three are still members of the
.University, the remaining having
been lost through graduation. It
is understood, however, that these
three men will have no preference
over the other candidates and last
year's substitutes, but because of
the wealth of new material said
to have entered college, will be
forced to prove their ability again
before regaining their places on
the regular five.
As was the case last year, all
the home games will be played at
the Fifth Regiment Armory. This
place not only affords excellent
playing facilities, but also offers
plenty of room for dancing after
the games. The dances last year
proved to be a great attraction
and so the announcement that
they will be continued this season
has met with much favorable comment around the University.
The tentative "at home" schedule follows:
December 16—Open.
December 24—N. Y. University
December 31—Penn State.
January 7—Swarthmore.
January 14—Rutgers.
January 21—Open.
January 28—Washington College.
February 11—Princeton.
February
18. — Trinity
or
Gettysburg.
March 4 or 11—Lehigh.
ATHLETIC BOARD MEETING.

At the meeting of the A.
A. Board Wednesday evening Theodore Gould was
elected manager of football
to complete the term of J.
E. Miller, and Bond Collins
was elected manager of track
to replace "Bill" FortneY,
who is black-listed.
The Board also ratified the
election of Charles Roland
Sharrets as baseball captain.

Black and Blue Downs Haverford
on Pennsylvania Field

R. 0. T. C. TO GIVE SECOND
EXHIBITION DRILL.

Team Returns with 17-10 Victory Calkins Makes Drop
Kick from 40 yd. Line in Third Period -Prospects Bright for HopkinsSt. Johns Battle.

On Tuesday, November 9, at
4.15.o'clock the R. 0. T. C. will
have. their second exhibition drill
of the year, which will be similar
to the guard mount of two weeks
ago, but of more importance.
The occasion will bring honor to
Hopkins, for Major Garey, head
of the Department of Military
• Science and Tactics, will be presented with a Distinguished Service Cross for gallantry in action
while serving in France. The
cross will be presented by MajorGeneral Cronkhite, commander of
the Third Army Corps, whose
headquarters is in Baltimore.
Following the presentation of
the medal the entire battalion,
led by the band from Camp Holabird, will pass in review before
President Goodnow. In addition
to the review there will be a formal guard mount, conducted by
Major Chism, with Lieutenant
Whittington in command of the
guard.
The Freshmen have in the past
month developed from raw recruits into soldiers who can execute all the foot movements and
the manual of arms with a surprising degree of efficiency.
Backed by the non-commissioned
officers of the sophomore class
and the upper class officers there
is little doubt that this drill will
be executed in a manner which
will be a credit to the University.
A number of visitors, including
officers of high rank,from Washington, are expected to be present. Students and friends of the
University are invited to witness
the drill.

The Johns Hopkins football team journeyed up to Pennsylvania
last Saturday and returned with 17-10 victory over Haverford College,
the first one for the Black and Blue in five years. The game was hardfought throughout, and devoted chiefly to old-style football, with a few
forward passes. From the first, Hopkins showed a decided advantage,
and was generally able to make substantial gains through the Quaker
line, although inside the 20-yard line the Niter played a wonderful
defensive game. It's a matter of fact, the contest was more one-sided
than the mere score indicates, for Hopkins made 11 first down to 4 for
Haverford, and in all probability might have had two more touchdowns if attempts for a field goal had not been made. The Black and
Blue also completed.four passes, while the Quakers worked only two of
many attempts.
Every man in the back field did his share in gaining ground, al'though Jones and Calkins were most successful in advancing the ball.
A notable improvement in defense against forward passes and in
tackling was seen, while time and again the Hopkins men broke through
and pulled down the Haverford runner for a loss. In the last period
nearly the whole Black and Blue line seemed to surge on and a dozen
hands catch an attempted pass that a moment later was turned into
the winning touchdown. Middleton and the Wood brothers were
always down the field under a kick, ready to drop the runner in his
tracks, and Middleton was right there in the third period to fall on a
fumbled ball, thus starting an advance that ended with a beautiful 40yard drop-kick by Calkins.
From the Haverford viewpoint the stars of the game were Macintosh, Hoopes and H. Sangree; the former kicked. a fine goal from
placement, Sangree scooped up Calkins' fumble and scored a touchdown, while Hoopes was the only Haverford man who could do anything at all with the Hopkins line.
The first quarter was scoreless
and indecisive, with neither team
showing much to be proud of.
Once, indeed, the Black and Blue
worked the ball to within 10 yards
of the line, but the Quakers smothered all attempts at a further advance and took the ball on downs.
With the second quarter, however,
Hopkins really got going, and in
eight plays Calkins had carried the
pigskin over for the first score.
Jones kicked goal.
Hopkins then received a n d
started another drive, which ended with an intercepted pass, but
Haverford lost ground on a bad
pass from center and then fumbled, Middleton recovering. The
half ended in a series of forwards
by both teams, without marked
success for either.
The third period brought hope
to the Pennsylvanian's rooters.
On the first play Calkins went
around end and then lost the ball;
II Sangree picked it up and ran

40 yards for a score. Following
the kickoff Hopkins gained ground
on a fumble recovered by Middleton, but was unable to advance;
Calkins then stepped back and
sent a 40-yard drop-kick between
the bars. Not to be outdone, the
Quakers soon approached thp goal
and sent Macintosh into the game
to score from a placement kick,
thus knotting the count at 10 all.
This seemed to put the final dash
of determination into the Hopkins
team, for from then on the game
was all their. Three consecutive
first downs and an intercepted
pass took the ball to within 8
yards of the line, from which
point a dash by Jones and a plunge
by Gregg put over the final marker. To the end of the game the
Black and Blue continued to advance, only to lose their gains in
uncalled-for attempts at field
goals.

SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB.
Mr. Ray Newton, representing
the Executive Council of the Intercollegiate Conference for Democracy, met the members of the
Social Science Club at the Johns
Hopkins Club on Monday, November 1. He explained that the organization which he represented
was a loose federation of the
social study groups in the leading
American colleges. He stated as
the purpose of the organization
the unpartisan study and investigation of the social and economic
problems of the day and the
furnishing of the individual members with speakers and data on
social and economic questions.
He emphasized the fact that the
nation is facing grave problems
which the college men of today
will be called upon to solve in the
near future.
The Intercollegiate Conference
for Democracy was formed this
summer from an informal gathering of representatives from American colleges and universities.
Mr. Fulton Bramble, secretary of
the Social Science Club, was the
unofficial representative of the
club.
The inducements offered to the
local club to join were aid in obtaining speakers and information
concerning economics and social
problems throughout the world.
However, it seems doubtful whether the club could obtain much
assistance from such an organization this year and no decision has
as yet been made as to whether or
not it will join at the present
time.

Mr. Walter Hampden, the distinguished Shakespearean actor,
last Thursday addressed what was
decidedly the most successful assembly held this year. After an
enthusiastic welcome which, he declared, was the best he had,received in Baltimore, the speaker
delivered a plea for the- development of the aesthetic, the artistic
side of our national life, without
which, he holds, no country may
be truly great.
Science and religion, he said,
are no more desirable and no more
essential to true happiness than
the appreciation of the beautiful
in all its forms—painting, sculpture, literature and the drama.
The last 50 years have seen too
much emphasis placed on the material prosperity of the nation, the
presence of which seems to many
to show real greatness, which can
in reality come only through the
development(of the other side of
human life.
Mr. Hampden believes that the
cultivation of the theater, an essentially democratic art, can do
much to bring this about. Through
the drama we pierce the externals
of civilization and reach a more
charming and inspiring atmosphere beyond; and in this no one
has been more successful than
Shakespeare, a man absolutely
modern in thought, who belongs
to all people and all time. "Hamlet," in particular, is a play which
is universal in its appeal, and
which can and does express something of the mind and feeling of
every one. No actor may speak
of "his Hamlet"; all that he can
do is to add something to the
storehouse of information and interpretation from which his successors will draw.
The speaker further declared
that he made no special plea for
the classics simply because they
were old, but simply for the true
beauty and truth to be found in
them. He wants new and modern plays, but plays which are
real and modern as Shakespeare
is real and modern, and which
take up the work where the great
men of former times left off. With
such an ideal in mind we may go
forward to the day when art will
receive its due share of attention
and appreciation and we shall
realize its necessity to true happiness.

DEBATING. .
The triangular debating contest, in which Hopkins finished
second last year, will be renewed
this year, with Johns Hopkins,
Washington and Lee and North
Carolina, last year's champions,
again constituting the Southern
Big Three in debating. After
much correspondence the Debating Council is able to announce
that the contests will be held in
accordance with contracts, similar
in every respect to those used last
year, save that the battle of wits
will be held earlier, probably in
March.
The subject of the debates has
not yet been fixed.
The local
council has called into consultation Dr. Barnett and Dr. Mitchell
to help them decide on and phrase
a proposition. The subject will
Probably be. one of economic importance, as that of last year dealt
with a political issue.
Representation in the Southern
Oratorical League necessitates
the choosing of an orator to speak
for Hopkins at the annual spring
competition. Try-outs for this
and other contests of interests to
Public speakers will be announced
by the Debating Council shortly.

Scientific Club.

Mr. Abel Walman presented to
the Scientific Club last Friday an
exceeding interesting lecture on
the subject "Dry Math for Wet
Problems."
This is only one of a series of
scientific lectures which the club
strives to provide weekly; many
more being planned for this year.
All men who are in any way interested are invited to come to
thee meetings which are held
every Friday at noon.

Junior Class Meeting,

Jack Dubbleedee was elected to
the Associate Hullabaloo Board
as Class Business Manager at the
class meeting held Tuesday at
12.30 o'clock.

The past few weeks of the J. H.
IT. Zionists' Society has been
spent in rounding out the organization of two study circles, namely, The Hebrew Conversation Circle and the General Zionists'
Circle. The former meets every
Tuesday at 12.30 o'clock in Room
113, Gilman Hall, and the latter
every Friday morning at 10.30
o'clock in Room 100, Gilman Hall.
Mr. William Chomsky is acting as
chairman of the Hebrew Circle,
while Mr. Fedder presides over the
Zionists' group. The membership
in both these groups is not over
25 and the Society urges all those
interested to attend the meetings.
Last week in the Zionists' History Circle an interesting general
discussion with reference to the
meaning and scope of Zionism was
held, and in the Hebrew meeting
Mr. Joseph Zubin lectured in
Hebrew on "Immigration in Palestine." The following week Mr.
Peretz will lecture on "Hebrew
Education," while Mr. Fedder in
read a paper on "Prends Messiah
and their relation to Zionism."

R. O. T. C.
The R. 0. T. C. Unit is being
whipped into shape and one can
already distinguish a straight line
during drill hours on Tuesday and
Thursday. Major Garey recognizes the fact that if the unit is
to give a creditable exhibition in
the inaugural parade next spring
a maximum amount of time will
have to be spent in drilling the
Freshmen. Toward this end the
Sophomores gave up their study
of map problems this week and
busied themselves in teaching the
first-year men the manual of arms
and other fundamentals. The
Juniors and Seniors were drilled
separately in the art of commanding troops. From 4.15 to 6 P. M.
the parade ground in front of Gilman Hall is a scene of activity
and anyone who is interested is
invited to come and see the makings of an "army." The next event
in the series of exhibitions given
for the benefit of outsiders will be
a battalion parade.

You have no doubt noticed the
jet black, water-proof derby that
"Pudgey" Upton has been wearing Saturday afternoons to the
football games. Some of the fellows are hoping he will get up
gumption enough to bring it to
school some day so that they could
show him how well it would look
folded like a felt hat.
The big fellow who has been
helping coach the football team
for the last week or so is Barney
O'Rourke, an old college mate of
Van Orman's. He was all-American tackle at Cornell at the same
time Van Orman was all-American end. Just for fun ask any of
the fellows who went on the training camp if they ever heard of
Barney's famous stiff arm.
We think that it would add materially to his appearance if Mr.
Hampden, the noted actor who
spoke at our last mass-meeting,
would follow Graham Heiner's
example and purchase a haircut.
Don't you?

to write up the game for their
paper and incidently to pay their
respects to some of the inmates of
Bryn Mawr.

Boone has recently returned from
France and has resumed his
studies (?) at the University.
Dr. Hulburt wishes to announce
to all students taking Math I or II
that it is wrong to plot only a
few points and then spend a
couple of hours trying to figure
what kind of a curve will fit them.
"Take time to find a goodly number of points," says the eminent
doctor, "and then draw in your
curve." The moral to be taken
from this is, Don't waste valuable
hours trying to polish an old flivver.

Advocates New Method of Profit-Sharing, But Admits That it is Not
Likely to Succeed.

Dr. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, professor
of philosophy at Johns Hopkins,
in the first of the series of public
lectures of the Social Science
Club, Thursday, proposed a plan
of profit-sharing on a 50-50 basis
for both capital and labor as a
means of obtaining industrial
peace.
Professor Lovejoy classified the
various profit-sharing plans into
three distinct types. The first
type, he said, was actuated by a
desire on the part of capital to
increase the income accruing to it;
this he called profit-sharing for
profit, or the illegitimate form of
profit-sharing. The second type of
profit-sharing he termed profitsharing for sharing in which both
employer and wage-earners would
derive benefits from an increase in
profits. The latter type was called
the legitimate form of profit-sharing. The third type of profitsharing is that espoused by Dr.
Lovejoy and bears the name of
profit-halving.
Professor Lovejoy describes his
plan as profit-sharing, not for the
sake of profits, but for the sake of
sharing. "In the long run," he
said, "it is true that it may turn
out to be profitable to all concerned; but it is not subject to the
initial condition that its adoption
shall be to the pecuniary advantage of capital as well as labor.
"It consists in a voluntary surrender by the present owners of
an enterprise of a substantial portion of any profit which may be
earned by it, not merely of a portion of the excess profits produced
by the sharing. If no increase of
earnings should result, the purpose
of this type of profit-sharing would
not be defeated."
Professor Lovejoy, however, is
dubious of the success of this plan.
"It would entail," he said, "too
great a sacrifice on the part of
thousands of stockholders whose
incomes would certainly be diminished for some time."

President of Musical Club Urges Encouraging of Music in the
University.

To the Editor of the Mail Bag:
Dear Sir—President Gilman,
the first President of Hopkins,
was a strong advocate of the doctrine that every man needs both
a vocation and an avocation to
help him make his way successfully through life.
There is no avocation more
beautiful, satisfying and refining
—none that can give so much
pleasure to others—as good music.
No matter how old, tired or
pressed with cares a man may be,
if he has learned to appreciate
music in his student days, or better still, has become himself a
musician, he has always at hand
a never-failing source of pleasure
to himself and others.
There has never been so great a
demand for good music as exists in
the world today, and the growth
of appreciation for music in our
schools, colleges and universities
has been remarkable. Many universities have departments of
music, in addition to choral societies, college choirs, symphony orchestras and military bands. A
large percentage of college
students are taking courses in
music, regarding it as an important part of their education.
Let us hope the day will come
when there will be a big auditorium on the campus at Homewood, with a fine organ, where
University gatherings can be held
and concerts and recitals given.
The University Orchestra, now
in its third season, is making excellent progress under the direction of Charles H. Bochau,
conductor, and Bart Wirtz, assistant conductor, two of Baltimore's leading musicians.
It
should have the hearty support
of the student-body, both graduate and undergraduate. In making membership open to outside
musicians we• have followed the
example of Columbia and other
universities and have thus been
enabled to get together a permanent and complete symphony orchestra, with all instruments represented.
The orchestra plays with the
greatest enthusiasm, and many of
the members come long distances
to attend rehearsals.
One who
lives 20 miles from Baltimore has
rarely been absent. I have heard
many of the musicians say "We
can hardly wait for Tuesday evening to come around."

TENTATIVE BASKETBALL
SCHEDULE ARRANGED.
Three Letter Men Back—Many Promising Candidates Available—Dances
Will Be Given After Home
Games at Armory.

The Hopkins Basketball Team
is scheduled to open its 1920-21
season at home with the New
York University Team. During
the year a large number of the
• strongest teams in the East will
be met, thus assuring another
successful basketball season.
Of the five regulars who played
on the Varsity team last year,
three are still members of the
.University, the remaining having
been lost through graduation. It
is understood, however, that these
three men will have no preference
over the other candidates and last
year's substitutes, but because of
the wealth of new material said
to have entered college, will be
forced to prove their ability again
before regaining their places on
the regular five.
As was the case last year, all
the home games will be played at
the Fifth Regiment Armory. This
place not only affords excellent
playing facilities, but also offers
plenty of room for dancing after
the games. The dances last year
proved to be a great attraction
and so the announcement that
they will be continued this season
has met with much favorable comment around the University.
The tentative "at home" schedule follows:
December 16—Open.
December 24—N. Y. University
December 31—Penn State.
January 7—Swarthmore.
January 14—Rutgers.
January 21—Open.
January 28—Washington College.
February 11—Princeton.
February
18. — Trinity
or
Gettysburg.
March 4 or 11—Lehigh.
ATHLETIC BOARD MEETING.

At the meeting of the A.
A. Board Wednesday evening Theodore Gould was
elected manager of football
to complete the term of J.
E. Miller, and Bond Collins
was elected manager of track
to replace "Bill" FortneY,
who is black-listed.
The Board also ratified the
election of Charles Roland
Sharrets as baseball captain.

4.15.o'clock the R. 0. T. C. will
have. their second exhibition drill
of the year, which will be similar
to the guard mount of two weeks
ago, but of more importance.
The occasion will bring honor to
Hopkins, for Major Garey, head
of the Department of Military
• Science and Tactics, will be presented with a Distinguished Service Cross for gallantry in action
while serving in France. The
cross will be presented by MajorGeneral Cronkhite, commander of
the Third Army Corps, whose
headquarters is in Baltimore.
Following the presentation of
the medal the entire battalion,
led by the band from Camp Holabird, will pass in review before
President Goodnow. In addition
to the review there will be a formal guard mount, conducted by
Major Chism, with Lieutenant
Whittington in command of the
guard.
The Freshmen have in the past
month developed from raw recruits into soldiers who can execute all the foot movements and
the manual of arms with a surprising degree of efficiency.
Backed by the non-commissioned
officers of the sophomore class
and the upper class officers there
is little doubt that this drill will
be executed in a manner which
will be a credit to the University.
A number of visitors, including
officers of high rank,from Washington, are expected to be present. Students and friends of the
University are invited to witness
the drill.

The Johns Hopkins football team journeyed up to Pennsylvania
last Saturday and returned with 17-10 victory over Haverford College,
the first one for the Black and Blue in five years. The game was hardfought throughout, and devoted chiefly to old-style football, with a few
forward passes. From the first, Hopkins showed a decided advantage,
and was generally able to make substantial gains through the Quaker
line, although inside the 20-yard line the Niter played a wonderful
defensive game. It's a matter of fact, the contest was more one-sided
than the mere score indicates, for Hopkins made 11 first down to 4 for
Haverford, and in all probability might have had two more touchdowns if attempts for a field goal had not been made. The Black and
Blue also completed.four passes, while the Quakers worked only two of
many attempts.
Every man in the back field did his share in gaining ground, al'though Jones and Calkins were most successful in advancing the ball.
A notable improvement in defense against forward passes and in
tackling was seen, while time and again the Hopkins men broke through
and pulled down the Haverford runner for a loss. In the last period
nearly the whole Black and Blue line seemed to surge on and a dozen
hands catch an attempted pass that a moment later was turned into
the winning touchdown. Middleton and the Wood brothers were
always down the field under a kick, ready to drop the runner in his
tracks, and Middleton was right there in the third period to fall on a
fumbled ball, thus starting an advance that ended with a beautiful 40yard drop-kick by Calkins.
From the Haverford viewpoint the stars of the game were Macintosh, Hoopes and H. Sangree; the former kicked. a fine goal from
placement, Sangree scooped up Calkins' fumble and scored a touchdown, while Hoopes was the only Haverford man who could do anything at all with the Hopkins line.
The first quarter was scoreless
and indecisive, with neither team
showing much to be proud of.
Once, indeed, the Black and Blue
worked the ball to within 10 yards
of the line, but the Quakers smothered all attempts at a further advance and took the ball on downs.
With the second quarter, however,
Hopkins really got going, and in
eight plays Calkins had carried the
pigskin over for the first score.
Jones kicked goal.
Hopkins then received a n d
started another drive, which ended with an intercepted pass, but
Haverford lost ground on a bad
pass from center and then fumbled, Middleton recovering. The
half ended in a series of forwards
by both teams, without marked
success for either.
The third period brought hope
to the Pennsylvanian's rooters.
On the first play Calkins went
around end and then lost the ball;
II Sangree picked it up and ran

40 yards for a score. Following
the kickoff Hopkins gained ground
on a fumble recovered by Middleton, but was unable to advance;
Calkins then stepped back and
sent a 40-yard drop-kick between
the bars. Not to be outdone, the
Quakers soon approached thp goal
and sent Macintosh into the game
to score from a placement kick,
thus knotting the count at 10 all.
This seemed to put the final dash
of determination into the Hopkins
team, for from then on the game
was all their. Three consecutive
first downs and an intercepted
pass took the ball to within 8
yards of the line, from which
point a dash by Jones and a plunge
by Gregg put over the final marker. To the end of the game the
Black and Blue continued to advance, only to lose their gains in
uncalled-for attempts at field
goals.

SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB.
Mr. Ray Newton, representing
the Executive Council of the Intercollegiate Conference for Democracy, met the members of the
Social Science Club at the Johns
Hopkins Club on Monday, November 1. He explained that the organization which he represented
was a loose federation of the
social study groups in the leading
American colleges. He stated as
the purpose of the organization
the unpartisan study and investigation of the social and economic
problems of the day and the
furnishing of the individual members with speakers and data on
social and economic questions.
He emphasized the fact that the
nation is facing grave problems
which the college men of today
will be called upon to solve in the
near future.
The Intercollegiate Conference
for Democracy was formed this
summer from an informal gathering of representatives from American colleges and universities.
Mr. Fulton Bramble, secretary of
the Social Science Club, was the
unofficial representative of the
club.
The inducements offered to the
local club to join were aid in obtaining speakers and information
concerning economics and social
problems throughout the world.
However, it seems doubtful whether the club could obtain much
assistance from such an organization this year and no decision has
as yet been made as to whether or
not it will join at the present
time.

Mr. Walter Hampden, the distinguished Shakespearean actor,
last Thursday addressed what was
decidedly the most successful assembly held this year. After an
enthusiastic welcome which, he declared, was the best he had,received in Baltimore, the speaker
delivered a plea for the- development of the aesthetic, the artistic
side of our national life, without
which, he holds, no country may
be truly great.
Science and religion, he said,
are no more desirable and no more
essential to true happiness than
the appreciation of the beautiful
in all its forms—painting, sculpture, literature and the drama.
The last 50 years have seen too
much emphasis placed on the material prosperity of the nation, the
presence of which seems to many
to show real greatness, which can
in reality come only through the
development(of the other side of
human life.
Mr. Hampden believes that the
cultivation of the theater, an essentially democratic art, can do
much to bring this about. Through
the drama we pierce the externals
of civilization and reach a more
charming and inspiring atmosphere beyond; and in this no one
has been more successful than
Shakespeare, a man absolutely
modern in thought, who belongs
to all people and all time. "Hamlet," in particular, is a play which
is universal in its appeal, and
which can and does express something of the mind and feeling of
every one. No actor may speak
of "his Hamlet"; all that he can
do is to add something to the
storehouse of information and interpretation from which his successors will draw.
The speaker further declared
that he made no special plea for
the classics simply because they
were old, but simply for the true
beauty and truth to be found in
them. He wants new and modern plays, but plays which are
real and modern as Shakespeare
is real and modern, and which
take up the work where the great
men of former times left off. With
such an ideal in mind we may go
forward to the day when art will
receive its due share of attention
and appreciation and we shall
realize its necessity to true happiness.

DEBATING. .
The triangular debating contest, in which Hopkins finished
second last year, will be renewed
this year, with Johns Hopkins,
Washington and Lee and North
Carolina, last year's champions,
again constituting the Southern
Big Three in debating. After
much correspondence the Debating Council is able to announce
that the contests will be held in
accordance with contracts, similar
in every respect to those used last
year, save that the battle of wits
will be held earlier, probably in
March.
The subject of the debates has
not yet been fixed.
The local
council has called into consultation Dr. Barnett and Dr. Mitchell
to help them decide on and phrase
a proposition. The subject will
Probably be. one of economic importance, as that of last year dealt
with a political issue.
Representation in the Southern
Oratorical League necessitates
the choosing of an orator to speak
for Hopkins at the annual spring
competition. Try-outs for this
and other contests of interests to
Public speakers will be announced
by the Debating Council shortly.

The past few weeks of the J. H.
IT. Zionists' Society has been
spent in rounding out the organization of two study circles, namely, The Hebrew Conversation Circle and the General Zionists'
Circle. The former meets every
Tuesday at 12.30 o'clock in Room
113, Gilman Hall, and the latter
every Friday morning at 10.30
o'clock in Room 100, Gilman Hall.
Mr. William Chomsky is acting as
chairman of the Hebrew Circle,
while Mr. Fedder presides over the
Zionists' group. The membership
in both these groups is not over
25 and the Society urges all those
interested to attend the meetings.
Last week in the Zionists' History Circle an interesting general
discussion with reference to the
meaning and scope of Zionism was
held, and in the Hebrew meeting
Mr. Joseph Zubin lectured in
Hebrew on "Immigration in Palestine." The following week Mr.
Peretz will lecture on "Hebrew
Education," while Mr. Fedder in
read a paper on "Prends Messiah
and their relation to Zionism."

R. O. T. C.
The R. 0. T. C. Unit is being
whipped into shape and one can
already distinguish a straight line
during drill hours on Tuesday and
Thursday. Major Garey recognizes the fact that if the unit is
to give a creditable exhibition in
the inaugural parade next spring
a maximum amount of time will
have to be spent in drilling the
Freshmen. Toward this end the
Sophomores gave up their study
of map problems this week and
busied themselves in teaching the
first-year men the manual of arms
and other fundamentals. The
Juniors and Seniors were drilled
separately in the art of commanding troops. From 4.15 to 6 P. M.
the parade ground in front of Gilman Hall is a scene of activity
and anyone who is interested is
invited to come and see the makings of an "army." The next event
in the series of exhibitions given
for the benefit of outsiders will be
a battalion parade.

You have no doubt noticed the
jet black, water-proof derby that

The big fellow who has been

time Van Orman was all-American end. Just for fun ask any of
the fellows who went on the training camp if they ever heard of
Barney's famous stiff arm.
We think that it would add materially to his appearance if Mr.
Hampden, the noted actor who
spoke at our last mass-meeting,
would follow Graham Heiner's
example and purchase a haircut.
Don't you?

Dr. Hulburt wishes to announce
to all students taking Math I or II
that it is wrong to plot only a
few points and then spend a
couple of hours trying to figure
what kind of a curve will fit them.
"Take time to find a goodly number of points," says the eminent
doctor, "and then draw in your
curve." The moral to be taken
from this is, Don't waste valuable
hours trying to polish an old flivver.

Advocates New Method of Profit-Sharing, But Admits That it is Not
Likely to Succeed.

Dr. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, professor
of philosophy at Johns Hopkins,
in the first of the series of public
lectures of the Social Science
Club, Thursday, proposed a plan
of profit-sharing on a 50-50 basis
for both capital and labor as a
means of obtaining industrial
peace.
Professor Lovejoy classified the
various profit-sharing plans into
three distinct types. The first
type, he said, was actuated by a
desire on the part of capital to
increase the income accruing to it;
this he called profit-sharing for
profit, or the illegitimate form of
profit-sharing. The second type of
profit-sharing he termed profitsharing for sharing in which both
employer and wage-earners would
derive benefits from an increase in
profits. The latter type was called
the legitimate form of profit-sharing. The third type of profitsharing is that espoused by Dr.
Lovejoy and bears the name of
profit-halving.
Professor Lovejoy describes his
plan as profit-sharing, not for the
sake of profits, but for the sake of
sharing. "In the long run," he
said, "it is true that it may turn
out to be profitable to all concerned; but it is not subject to the
initial condition that its adoption
shall be to the pecuniary advantage of capital as well as labor.
"It consists in a voluntary surrender by the present owners of
an enterprise of a substantial portion of any profit which may be
earned by it, not merely of a portion of the excess profits produced
by the sharing. If no increase of
earnings should result, the purpose
of this type of profit-sharing would
not be defeated."
Professor Lovejoy, however, is
dubious of the success of this plan.
"It would entail," he said, "too
great a sacrifice on the part of
thousands of stockholders whose
incomes would certainly be diminished for some time."

President of Musical Club Urges Encouraging of Music in the
University.

To the Editor of the Mail Bag:
Dear Sir—President Gilman,
the first President of Hopkins,
was a strong advocate of the doctrine that every man needs both
a vocation and an avocation to
help him make his way successfully through life.
There is no avocation more
beautiful, satisfying and refining
—none that can give so much
pleasure to others—as good music.
No matter how old, tired or
pressed with cares a man may be,
if he has learned to appreciate
music in his student days, or better still, has become himself a
musician, he has always at hand
a never-failing source of pleasure
to himself and others.
There has never been so great a
demand for good music as exists in
the world today, and the growth
of appreciation for music in our
schools, colleges and universities
has been remarkable. Many universities have departments of
music, in addition to choral societies, college choirs, symphony orchestras and military bands. A
large percentage of college
students are taking courses in
music, regarding it as an important part of their education.
Let us hope the day will come
when there will be a big auditorium on the campus at Homewood, with a fine organ, where
University gatherings can be held
and concerts and recitals given.
The University Orchestra, now
in its third season, is making excellent progress under the direction of Charles H. Bochau,
conductor, and Bart Wirtz, assistant conductor, two of Baltimore's leading musicians.
It
should have the hearty support
of the student-body, both graduate and undergraduate. In making membership open to outside
musicians we• have followed the
example of Columbia and other
universities and have thus been
enabled to get together a permanent and complete symphony orchestra, with all instruments represented.
The orchestra plays with the
greatest enthusiasm, and many of
the members come long distances
to attend rehearsals.
One who
lives 20 miles from Baltimore has
rarely been absent. I have heard
many of the musicians say "We
can hardly wait for Tuesday evening to come around."
